Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Re-inventing the Nation's Urban Water Infrastructure

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration: The Engineering Research Center for Re-Inventing the Nation's Urban Water Infrastructure (ReNUWIt) was funded in 2011 to facilitate the transition of water systems to a new state in which they consume less energy and resources while continuing to meet the needs of urban users and aquatic ecosystems. This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site will provide an enhanced, cohesive program to a cohort of undergraduates each summer and will target highly qualified science and engineering students from diverse backgrounds with an emphasis on women and minorities. The student-learning outcomes of the project focus on engaging and creating enthusiasm for science and engineering. The test-bed facilities provide ample opportunities for hands-on experience in multidisciplinary research activities at the four geographically and ethnically diverse institutions. ReNUWIt post-docs and graduate students will gain mentoring experiences in working closely with REU participants. Research communication skills of REU participants will improve through report writing, poster preparation, roundtables, and seminar presentations. This REU Site is supported by the Division of Engineering Education and Centers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The summer NSF REU Site: "Re-inventing the Nation's Urban Water Infrastructure" provided 9-10 week mentored research for visiting undergraduates interested in water science and engineering. REU participants joined research labs directed by faculty in the NSF Engineering Research Center for Re-inventing the Nation's Urban Water Infrastructure (ReNUWIt) at Stanford University, Colorado School of Mines, New Mexico State University, and University of California at Berkeley. Participants learned laboratory/field techniques, were immersed in ReNUWIt’s collaborative and interdisciplinary culture, and conducted meaningful research in state-of-the-art facilities. REU participants also interacted directly with ReNUWIt faculty and peers, received professional development training, and experienced ReNUWIt’s systems-level approach to addressing the nation’s water issues.

Intellectual Merit:

Participants entered the program with a variety of majors, including environmental engineering, civil engineering, biological systems engineering, chemical engineering, environmental science, chemistry, biology, and geology. They conducted research within ReNUWIt's three research thrust areas: Natural Water Infrastructure Systems, Efficient Engineered Systems, and Urban Systems Integration and Institutions. The main objectives of the Site were (1) to provide participating students with hands-on research expeirences using cross-disciplinary, systems-level approaches that directly address the design of urban water infrastructure and key knowledge gaps in water science/engineering and (2) to increase undergraduate students' interests in pursuing advanced degrees in water science/engineering, with a particular emphasis on women and underrepresented groups. Program alumni and their projects are highlighted on ReNUWIt's website: http://renuwit.org/education/reu-program/

Broader Impacts:

A total of 50 undergradautes (33 female, 19 from underrepresented groups) participated in the program during Summers 2013-2016, many coming from four-year institutions without STEM PhD programs and often without access to research opportunities common in larger research institutions. Professional development foci included oral research communication to various audiences, technical writing, data visualization, academia and career paths, and building cohesive research teams. REU participants gained access to the network of ReNUWIt researchers and alumni on our four partner campuses. To date, twenty-one (21) ReNUWIt REU alumni have pursued graduate school (MS and/or PhD). This REU Site has contributed to the growth and diversification of the STEM workforce, and will continue to do so.
